where e1 = r1[1]↷r3[3], e2 = r3[3]↷r2[3] and e3 = r2[3]↷r1[1]. By deﬁning g to be
the composition fe3 ◦fe2 ◦fe1, we get that the permutation associated toC is πG(C) =
[g(1),g(2),g(3)] = [1,2,3] = id3. Hence, the ﬁrst condition of the Deﬁnition 1.4 is
satisﬁed. Due to the edge r1[1]↷r3[3], the second condition is also satisﬁed. Thus,
Σ is non-conﬂicting.
The following example shows that during the construction of the chase of a
database with respect to a set of non-conﬂicting CDs, a KD may be violated which
implies that the KD chase rule must be applied.
Example 1.7. Consider the set Σ of non-conﬂicting CDs given in Example 1.4. Let
D = {professor(p),leads(p,g)}. During the construction of chase(D,Σ), we add
the atoms member(p), works in(p,g) and works in(p,z1), where z1 ∈ΓN. The KD
key(works in) = {1} of Σ implies that p cannot participates more than once in
Works in as the ﬁrst component. Thus, we deduce that z1 = g. We must therefore
replace each occurrence of z1 with g in the part of the chase(D,Σ) constructed so
far.
